Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Plasmochemistry and Photochemistry of the Upper Atmosphere Induced by Transient Luminous Events
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will investigate lightning as a source for high-altitude optical emissions known as transient luminous events (TLEs). The objectives of the investigation are to quantify the plasmochemical and photochemical effects of TLEs in the upper atmosphere and to reveal possible pathways of atmospheric species upon impact by short, impulsive external forces. These goals will be achieved by developing and applying a self-consistent plasma chemistry and photochemistry model for TLEs, remote sensing of TLEs through optical spectroscopy, continuous data acquisition by building and maintaining a TLE observation site at Florida Tech, and comparing modeling results with satellite measurements and high-speed video observations from ground.

The educational objectives of the project are to train the next generation of researchers in the areas of aeronomy and to foster the interest of high school students and general public in atmospheric sciences. The education activities include: 1) graduate and undergraduate student training, 2) curriculum development by incorporating elements of the research into classroom, 3) building a TLE website for data sharing and public outreach, and 4) improving high school science education by participating in the Florida Tech InSTEP program, an NSF-funded GK-12 program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Occurrences of large electrical discharges above thunderstorms were predicted by Nobel Laureate, C. T. R. Wilson, back in 1925. It however was not until late 1980s and early 1990s that their existence is confirmed by observations. Now, we know that thunderstorm and lightning activity can cause a variety of electrical discharges that have distinct morphologies and span different atmosphere regions. They have been given a common name of transient luminous events (TLEs) but can be classified as starters, jets, gigantic jets, sprites, halos and elves. Starters are column or fan shape of discharges shooting upward from thundercloud tops to 20-30 km altitude; jets and gigantic jets are similar to starters in their origins but can reach 40-50 km and 70-90 km, respectively; sprites are typically initiated at much higher altitudes of about 75 km and extend both downward and upward; halos are pancake shape of glows centered at 75-85 km altitude; and elves are fast-expanding luminous rings at 85-95 km altitude. TLEs are directly related to lightning activity, and they are either caused by lightning or initiated like normal lightning inside thunderclouds.

Observations, numerical modeling and data analysis were preformed during the course of this project to study the physical mechanisms of TLEs, their effects in the corresponding atmosphere layers, and their roles in the coupling between lower and upper atmosphere layers. A video observation station to study TLEs has been established at the east coast of Florida. Many TLEs have been captured, including a sequence of starters, jets and gigantic jets above a thunderstorm associated with Tropical Depression Dorian in 2013. The recording is probably the best currently available to show the dynamical features of those events and has been featured in many news reports. Our analysis of various storm and lightning data for those events indicates that they all began as normal intracloud lightning deep inside the thundercloud and transferred about 400 C negative charge from a deep thunderstorm region to the lower ionosphere during a period of less than thirty minutes. Although this amount of charge is only a few thousandths of the total charge in earth’s upper atmosphere, the electrodynamic transients generated can be significant, given that the charge transfer is so rapid and that only a very small ionospheric volume is in direct contact with the discharges. Our further analysis of this storm and other jet-producing storms has found that they share common properties including intense convection and strong wind shear near the storm tops. This means that sheared, deep tropical convection systems, which are not terribly unusual, have a good chance to produce those events, providing guidelines on what storms to look for in order to study those fascinating discharges.

We have found from our study that other types of TLEs can also significantly modify the ionospheric volumes they occupy. Sprites, halos and elves are caused by impulsive cloud-to-ground lightning discharges (CGs). As an impulsive CG discharge quickly moves a large amount of charge from a thunderstorm to ground, strong electromagnetic field is produced, which can accelerate ionospheric electrons to cause sprites, halos and elves. We have studied a few halos and sprites observed by our camera system that were caused by extremely impulsive CGs and have found that the lower ionosphere was significantly modified. In particular, the lower ionospheric density might have been increased by nearly four orders of magnitude due to the most intense CG among that dataset. Another study conducted by us found that those intense CGs are produced by storms with strong turbulence at their tops. This indicates that turbulence in the lower atmosphere can be coupled to the upper atmosphere nearly instantly through TLEs.

We further investigated how long the ionospheric density perturbations created by TLEs last and how they are dissipated. Below 75 km altitude, the ionospheric electron density recovers in a few seconds due to a fast electron attachment process. The recovery time above 75 km altitude is controlled by a slower recombination process, and can last tens of minutes to hours depending on the ambient density profile.

Another research subject that we focused on was initiation of fine structure of sprites known as sprite streamers. We have found that mesospheric perturbations are required to initiate them and an electron detachment process plays an important role in their initiation.

This project has provided excellent training opportunities for a dozen of undergraduate and graduate students, and contributed to the development of the STEM workforce. It has generated curriculum materials for undergraduate and graduate physics courses at Florida Institute of Technology. It has also resulted in two master’s theses and two doctoral dissertations, and has provided research experiences required for bachelor’s degrees at Florida Institute of Technology for several undergraduate students.
